questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

In the context of acute inflammation, most plasma proteins, known as acute-phase reactants, typically increase due to the influence of cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-1 (IL-1). These are referred to as positive acute-phase reactants.

 

However, there are certain proteins, called negative acute-phase reactants, that decrease during acute inflammation. Albumin is one such protein. The decrease in albumin during inflammation is thought to help conserve amino acids for the production of more essential proteins needed during the inflammatory response. Additionally, lower albumin levels help to reduce blood viscosity and facilitate the movement of immune cells to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a well-known positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels significantly increase during inflammation, making it a common marker for detecting inflammation.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute-phase reactant. It increases during inflammation and plays a role in iron metabolism, often contributing to the anemia seen in chronic disease.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin, an iron-storage protein, also acts as a positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels rise during inflammation, reflecting increased storage of iron in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin

 

Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin

questions.text: What is the typical sequence of color changes observed in a common superficial bruise? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Red-Blue-Brown-Green-Yellow-Normal).

 

Explanation:

 

The color changes in a bruise follow a predictable sequence as the hemoglobin in the extravasated blood undergoes degradation. Initially, the bruise appears red due to the presence of oxygenated hemoglobin. Within a few hours to 3 days, it turns blue due to deoxygenated hemoglobin. By the 4th-5th day, the bruise appears bluish-black to brown as hemosiderin (an iron-storage complex) forms. Around the 5th-6th day, the bruise turns green due to the formation of biliverdin (a green pigment formed during hemoglobin breakdown). Finally, between the 7th-14th day, the bruise turns yellow due to bilirubin formation. After about 2 weeks, the bruise disappears as the normal skin color returns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red-Blue-Green-Brown-Yellow-Normal - This sequence is incorrect because brown (hemosiderin) precedes green (biliverdin) in the degradation process.

 

Option C. Red-Blue-Brown-Yellow-Green-Normal - This sequence is incorrect because green (biliverdin) precedes yellow (bilirubin) in the hemoglobin breakdown pathway.

 

Option D. Red-Yellow-Blue-Brown-Green-Normal - This sequence is entirely incorrect as yellow appears much later in the bruise evolution, not early.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The color change sequence in a bruise follows the biochemical degradation of hemoglobin: red (oxygenated blood) → blue (deoxygenated hemoglobin) → brown (hemosiderin) → green (biliverdin) → yellow (bilirubin) → normal skin color.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia. On further evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and episodes of epilepsy were observed. A CT scan of the brain was performed What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

 

Explanation: 


The presentation indicates temporal lobe abscess because:

 

  • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT
  • Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: 
    • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement
    • Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression
    • Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • Common complication of CSOM due to: 
    • Direct extension through tegmen tympani

    • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM

       

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis

 

  • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM
  • No discrete abscess formation on imaging
  • Shows meningeal enhancement
  • Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)

 

Option C. Subdural abscess

 

  • Collection between dura and arachnoid
  • Different imaging appearance
  • No discrete parenchymal involvement
  • Different clinical presentation

 

Option D. Extradural abscess

 

  • Collection outside dura but intracranial
  • Different imaging appearance
  • Less severe neurological symptoms
  • No parenchymal involvement

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, presenting with seizures and characteristic CT findings of a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

questions.text: Sodium benzoate is given for urea cycle defects for scavenging ammonia. Which amino acid donates amino group to the scavengers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Sodium benzoate acts as an ammonia scavenger in urea cycle disorders. It works by conjugating with glycine to form hippurate (or hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine. This process provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion when the urea cycle is impaired. The reaction occurs without requiring the urea cycle, thus helping to reduce ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is actually a component of the urea cycle itself and is often supplemented in some urea cycle disorders (except arginase deficiency). It does not directly conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia removal.

 

Option C. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved with another ammonia scavenger, phenyl butyrate, which is converted to phenyl acetate and then conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. However, glutamine does not conjugate with sodium benzoate.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid that participates in the urea cycle by providing one of the nitrogen atoms for urea formation. It does not conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders, sodium benzoate is used as an ammonia scavenger that conjugates specifically with glycine to form hippurate (hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine.

choices.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.
It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.
It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

 

Ciclesonide is an inhalational corticosteroid used to manage asthma and other respiratory conditions.

 

It is unique among inhaled corticosteroids because it is a "soft steroid" and functions as a prodrug. This means that Ciclesonide is inactive when administered and only becomes active when it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases. This activation in the target site, the bronchial airways, significantly reduces the drug's systemic side effects, including the risk of oral candidiasis, which is common with other inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Because the majority of the drug that deposits in the oropharynx remains inactive, the likelihood of developing oral candidiasis (a common side effect of other inhalational steroids due to local immunosuppression) is significantly lower with Ciclesonide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids: This statement is correct. Due to its activation in the bronchial tree, Ciclesonide has fewer systemic and local side effects compared to other inhalational corticosteroids.

 

Option C. It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase: This is also correct. Ciclesonide remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases.

 

Option D. It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids: This is correct. Ciclesonide is just as effective as other inhalational corticosteroids in managing respiratory conditions such as asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.

questions.text: An employee who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis is eligible for an extended sickness benefit for? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 years

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948, employees who are diagnosed with specific long-term illnesses, including tuberculosis, are eligible for an extended sickness benefit. This benefit provides financial support to cover a significant portion of their wages during prolonged periods of illness. The extended sickness benefit offers 80% of the employee's wages for up to 2 years. This provision ensures that employees have continued financial support while they are unable to work due to their medical condition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the family cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Formation → extension → contraction → dissolution

 

Explanation:

 

The family cycle consists of the following 6 stages in the correct sequence:

 

  1. Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child.
  2. Extension: From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child.
  3. Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home
  4. Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home
  5. Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse
  6. Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.

 

The correct sequence is formation, extension, contraction, and finally, dissolution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution, representing the stages from marriage to the death of the surviving spouse.

questions.text: A patient present with Cotton wool skull. Most likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's disease

 

  • Paget's disease of bone, also known as osteitis deformans, is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and misshapen bones. 
  • The condition is named after Sir James Paget, who first described it. 
  • The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull is a radiological hallmark of Paget's disease, resulting from the irregular thickening and softening of the bone. 
  • This appearance is due to a chaotic remodelling process where excessive bone resorption is followed by disorganized bone formation.
  • Thus, the skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Increasing Hat Size!

 

 

Additional Information:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocyotsis: The radiological imaging of the skull in Langerhans cell histiocytosis shows solitary or multiple punched-out lytic lesions without sclerotic rim; double contour or beveled edge appearance due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer; button sequestrum representing residual bone; and geographic skull. 

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Salt and pepper sign due to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria caused by resorption of trabecular bone in hyperparathyroidism. There is a loss of definition between the inner and outer tables of the skull; a ground-glass appearance; and spotty deossification.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Radiographically, multiple myeloma appears as multiple, “punched-out”, sharply demarcated, purely lytic lesions without any surrounding reactive sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull on radiographs is a classic sign of Paget's disease. 
  • This pattern results from the chaotic bone remodelling process characteristic of this condition.

choices.text: The presence of contralateral mediastinal lymph nodes precludes surgical resection
For patients over 70 years with advanced disease, single-agent chemotherapy is preferred
Among the Asian population, squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC
Gefitinib shows the highest efficacy in female smokers with adenocarcinoma

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (NSCLC) are accurate, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Among the Asian population, squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC

 

In Asian populations, adenocarcinoma (not squamous cell carcinoma) is the most common histologic type of NSCLC. This demographic pattern is important because it correlates with the higher prevalence of EGFR mutations observed in Asian patients, which has significant implications for treatment selection and response to targeted therapies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of contralateral mediastinal lymph nodes precludes surgical resection: Contralateral mediastinal lymph node involvement (N3 disease) indicates stage IIIB disease, which is generally considered unresectable. This represents locally advanced disease where surgery would not provide survival benefit.

 

Option B. For patients over 70 years with advanced disease, single-agent chemotherapy is preferred: For elderly patients (>70 years) with advanced NSCLC, single-agent chemotherapy is often preferred due to reduced toxicity while maintaining modest efficacy. This approach provides a better risk-benefit ratio in this population.

 

Option D. Gefitinib shows the highest efficacy in female smokers with adenocarcinoma: This statement is incorrect. Gefitinib, an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, shows highest efficacy in female NON-smokers with adenocarcinoma histology. Smoking status is a critical negative predictor of response to EGFR inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epidemiology of NSCLC varies by population, with adenocarcinoma being the predominant subtype in Asian populations, associated with higher rates of EGFR mutations that impact therapeutic approaches and response to targeted therapies.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with vomiting and constipation. On examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS

 

Explanation:

 

Clinical features strongly suggest CHPS:

 

  • CHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • It typically presents in males, around 4-8 weeks of age.
  • Electrolyte abnormality: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric acid and dehydration.
  • Best initial test: Ultrasound abdomen → Shows a thickened pyloric muscle (> 4mm thick, > 16mm long).
  • Treatment: Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy (surgical incision of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Incorrect as it presents at birth with bilious vomiting and double-bubble sign on X-ray

 

 

Option B. Intussusception: Incorrect as it occurs in infants 6-18 months of age and presents with red currant jelly stools

 

 

Option D. Hirschsprung's disease: Incorrect as it presents at birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours and has delayed passage of stools

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS classically presents at 4-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting and palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastrium.

 

Infantile Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS)

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HOCM

 

The murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) typically increases on standing. This is due to the decreased venous return and preload that occur with standing, which result in a reduction in the size of the left ventricular cavity. The smaller cavity size exacerbates the outflow obstruction under the aortic valve, thereby intensifying the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Regurgitation (MR): The murmur associated with MR typically decreases when standing due to the decreased venous return and reduced volume load on the left ventricle, which lessens the regurgitant flow across the mitral valve.

 

Option C. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): The murmur of a VSD generally decreases on standing due to reduced left to right shunting caused by decreased venous return.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis (MS): The murmur of mitral stenosis also decreases on standing. The reduction in preload lessens the flow through the narrowed mitral valve, subsequently reducing the intensity of the murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options listed, the murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy is unique in that it increases on standing, due to the specific hemodynamic changes that accentuate the outflow obstruction. This characteristic can be a crucial diagnostic clue in the clinical assessment of murmurs.

 

Reference - Harrison/Physical examination of CVS/Chap 239

choices.text: Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased
Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with diabetes has high increased LDL and VLDL because of (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased


In diabetes, there is either a deficiency of insulin or insulin resistance. Insulin normally inhibits hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). When insulin is deficient or not working properly, HSL activity increases while LPL activity decreases. HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue, releasing fatty acids into circulation. Increased HSL activity leads to more triglycerides being broken down. Meanwhile, decreased LPL activity reduces the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins from the bloodstream. This combined effect results in elevated levels of VLDL and subsequently LDL in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, these two enzymes are regulated in opposite directions. While HSL is increased, LPL is decreased due to the lack of insulin's regulatory effect.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased: This is the opposite of what occurs in diabetes. This pattern would be seen in a fed state with normal insulin action, not in diabetes.

 

Option D. Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, HSL is increased, not decreased. While LPL is indeed decreased in diabetes, both enzymes are not decreased.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) activity is increased while lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is decreased due to insulin deficiency or resistance, leading to elevated levels of VLDL and LDL.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

The clinical presentation of a swollen belly and dull face in a child fed mostly rice water, along with findings of low serum protein and low albumin, is suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by:

 

  • Edema: Resulting from hypoalbuminemia, which leads to fluid retention and swelling, especially in the abdomen.
  • Apathy and irritability: The child often appears listless and irritable.
  • Poor diet history: Often associated with diets low in protein, such as those predominantly consisting of carbohydrates like rice water.
  • Other symptoms: Growth retardation, muscle wasting, and skin and hair changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe acute malnutrition but is characterized by severe wasting and absence of edema. Children with marasmus appear extremely thin with prominent ribs and have a "skin and bones" appearance.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This is a chronic liver disease in children characterized by liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, but it does not typically present with the acute signs of protein malnutrition like Kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: This is an acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children under 5 years of age and involves inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis). It does not present with symptoms of malnutrition such as a swollen belly due to low protein intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

questions.text: A few hours following forceps delivery, patient complained of pain in perineum. On examination, she had hypotension, tachycardia and the episiotomy site had a large bluish swelling. Which of the following should not be done? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repair in ward

 

The clinical scenario describes a vulval hematoma, which is a serious postpartum complication. The patient presents with classical symptoms:

 

  • Pain in perineum
  • Hypotension and tachycardia indicating shock
  • Large bluish swelling at episiotomy site. This condition requires immediate intervention, but attempting repair in the ward would be dangerous and inappropriate. The patient requires proper surgical management in controlled conditions.
  • A repair in the ward is hence completely un-indicated in her. Drainage of the hematoma and obliteration of dead space has to be done in the OT with proper lighting and assistance and at the same time shock needs to be managed by resuscitation with fluids and blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood transfusion: Correct step. The patient is in shock with hypotension and tachycardia, indicating significant blood loss into the hematoma. Blood transfusion is essential for resuscitation.

 

Option C. Inform senior: Correct step. Given the severity of the condition and need for surgical intervention, senior consultation is necessary.

 

Option D. Shift to OT: Correct step. The patient requires evacuation of hematoma and obliteration of dead space under proper anesthesia, which can only be done in an operation theater.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A vulval hematoma presenting after delivery requires immediate resuscitation and surgical evacuation in the operation theater, never repair in the ward, due to:

 

  • Need for proper anesthesia
  • Potential for significant blood loss
  • Presence of dead space requiring proper surgical obliteration
  • Risk of shock

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed, which revealed multiple ring-enhancing lesions. What will be the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MR spectroscopy

 

MR spectroscopy is the next best step when multiple ring-enhancing lesions are observed in the basal parts of the brain, suggesting tuberculomas. MR spectroscopy helps differentiate tuberculomas from other similar conditions, like neurocysticercosis (NCC), by identifying a characteristic lipid-lactate peak. The presence of this peak strongly favors a diagnosis of tuberculosis rather than NCC, which typically does not show this peak. This approach is a non-invasive and specific method to further evaluate the lesions, aligning with standard clinical protocols.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CBNAAT of CSF: CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) of CSF is mainly used for confirming tuberculous meningitis rather than localized brain lesions such as tuberculomas. It is not useful in directly evaluating ring-enhancing lesions seen on MRI.

 

Option C. Biopsy: Biopsy is an invasive procedure and is usually not the first choice due to potential complications. It is reserved for cases where non-invasive methods fail to provide a definitive diagnosis.

 

Option D. SWI (Susceptibility-Weighted Imaging): SWI is used primarily for detecting bleeds, microhemorrhages, or diffuse axonal injuries. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of ring-enhancing lesions caused by infections like tuberculosis or neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal brain region on MRI suggests tuberculomas, and MR spectroscopy is the preferred next step to confirm the diagnosis by detecting a lipid-lactate peak.

choices.text: It can cause scleroderma which makes injecting insulin difficult.
It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypertriglyceridemia is considered for niacin therapy. She is a known diabetic managed adequately with sugars well under control. Why should niacin be used cautiously in this patient?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It can cause hyperglycemia.

 

  • Niacin has been associated with an increase in blood glucose levels, which can lead to hyperglycemia. This effect can be concerning for individuals with diabetes, especially if their blood sugar levels are well-controlled. Therefore, caution is needed when considering niacin therapy in diabetic patients to prevent the risk of elevated blood sugar levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It can cause scleroderma which makes injecting insulin difficult: There is no known direct association between niacin therapy and scleroderma. Scleroderma is a separate medical condition characterized by the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It is not a common side effect of niacin therapy.

 

Option C. It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs: Niacin is not typically known to increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs. However, it is essential for diabetic patients to monitor their blood sugar levels closely when starting niacin therapy, as it may interact with their existing medications.

 

Option D. It can cause hypoglycemia: Niacin is not known to cause hypoglycemia. In fact, the primary concern with niacin therapy in diabetic patients is the potential for elevated blood sugar levels (hyperglycemia).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin can cause increase in blood sugar levels by inducing insulin resistance and decreasing glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Hence, it should be used cautiously in diabetic patients. When prescribed, weekly monitoring of blood sugars is required.

questions.text: A neonate presents with fecal discharge from the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileal diverticulum

 

Ileal diverticulum, commonly known as Meckel's diverticulum, is a congenital anomaly resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct. This condition can result in a persistent connection between the intestine and the umbilicus. If this connection forms a fistula, fecal matter can discharge from the umbilicus.

Meckel's diverticulum often follows the "Rule of 2's": it occurs in about 2% of the population, is located approximately 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and is about 2 inches long. Symptoms often appear before the age of 2, and it can contain two types of ectopic tissue: gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: This is a congenital defect where the abdominal wall does not form completely, leading to the intestines being exposed outside the body without a covering sac. It does not involve the formation of a fistula that would allow fecal discharge through the umbilicus.

 

Option B. Urachal fistula: This condition involves a patent urachus, a remnant of the allantois that normally obliterates after birth. It leads to urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal matter, as it connects the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Omphalocele: This is a congenital defect in which the intestines, liver, and other organs remain outside the abdomen in a sac due to failure of the abdominal wall to close. It does not involve a fistula formation with the intestine, so fecal discharge does not occur from the umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel's diverticulum, due to its persistence of the vitelline duct, can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, particularly when a fistula is present.

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

 

Clinical history is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Presence of low TSH with suspected hypothyroidism indicates loss of Log relationship of TSH & fT4 indicating a central cause. Administration of TRH improving TSH level indicates TRH deficiency which is mainly produced from the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Hyperthyroidism due to pituitary:  Cause like TSHoma is very rare. Also, symptoms of thyrotoxicosis are not present in the patient.

 

Option B. In pituitary disease: TSH will not improve with TRH administration as the gland is defective and cannot produce TSH.

 

Option D. Thyrotoxicosis symptoms are not present in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a patient with hypothyroid symptoms and low TSH that responds to TRH administration, consider hypothalamic dysfunction as a probable cause. This is indicative of secondary hypothyroidism due to a lack of TRH production, affecting the pituitary’s secretion of TSH in the absence of exogenous stimulation.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hypothyroidism/Chap 383

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. His cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows increased opening pressure and positive India ink staining for encapsulated yeast. What is the recommended treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amphotericin B (AMB) + Flucytosine

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are consistent with cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The positive India ink staining revealing encapsulated yeast cells is diagnostic. For complicated cases involving CNS infection, the recommended first-line treatment is combination therapy with Amphotericin B and Flucytosine. This combination provides synergistic antifungal activity and better penetration into the CNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: While fluconazole can be used for uncomplicated cryptococcal infections or as maintenance therapy, it is not the first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Although effective, monotherapy with Amphotericin B is less effective than combination therapy.

 

Option D. Fluconazole + Amphotericin B: This combination is not the standard recommended therapy for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The recommended first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis is combination therapy with Amphotericin B and Flucytosine.

questions.text: 15-year-old girl with wide-spaced nipples, short height, and the following karyotype: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome


Turner syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of only one X chromosome (45, X) rather than the typical two sex chromosomes (XX or XY). The karyotype shown confirms the absence of the Y chromosome and only one X chromosome, which is diagnostic of Turner syndrome. Clinical features often include short stature, wide-spaced nipples, webbed neck, and other physical anomalies. Turner syndrome is a common genetic condition tested in exams due to its distinctive features and significant clinical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY). It does not fit the description of a 15-year-old girl with the specific karyotype shown and is not associated with the physical characteristics described.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is characterized by trisomy 21 (an extra chromosome 21) and typically presents with distinct facial features, intellectual disability, and other health issues. The karyotype shown does not match Down syndrome.

 

Option D. Partial mole: A partial mole is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease involving an abnormal pregnancy with an extra set of paternal chromosomes, often presenting with symptoms related to pregnancy and abnormal placental tissue rather than the clinical features described here.

 

Educational Objective:


Turner syndrome is characterized by the karyotype 45,X, and typical clinical features include short stature and wide-spaced nipples, commonly seen in females.

choices.text: NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available
NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

questions.text: The image of the mascot ‘Sapna’ shown below and identify what does she represent in the national health program: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

 

'Sapna' is the mascot of National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP) in India. She represents the success story of leprosy treatment, as she herself was a leprosy patient who got completely cured after taking multi-drug therapy (MDT). Her role is to spread awareness about:

 

  • Curability of leprosy through MDT
  • Reducing stigma and discrimination associated with leprosy in society
  • Encouraging early detection and treatment seeking behavior
  • Demonstrating that leprosy patients can lead a normal life after treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available: Incorrect because there is no widely accepted vaccine for leprosy currently available for public use

 

Option B. NLEP, Leprosy has been eliminated: While India achieved elimination status (<1 case/10,000 population) in December 2005, the program continues as new cases still occur

 

Option D. NLEP, leprosy can't affect children: Incorrect as leprosy can affect people of any age group including children

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sapna is the mascot of NLEP who represents successful treatment of leprosy and aims to reduce stigma while spreading awareness about curability of the disease through multi-drug therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and is diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia without atypia based on an endometrial biopsy. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)

 

Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is a premalignant condition caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, leading to excessive proliferation of the endometrial glands. 

 

The primary concern with endometrial hyperplasia is its potential progression to endometrial carcinoma, though the risk is much lower in cases without atypia (approximately 1%).

 

LNG-IUS (Mirena) -progesterone is the mainstay treatment because it induces endometrial atrophy and prevents further proliferation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. COCPs (Incorrect): Although Combined contraceptive pills are protective for endometrial cancer, they are not a treatment option for endometrial hyperplasia due to the estrogen component. 

 

Option C. Danazol (Incorrect): Danazol is an antigonadotropin with significant androgenic side effects. While it was historically used for endometriosis, it is not used for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Mifepristone (Incorrect): Mifepristone is primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy and occasionally for emergency contraception or fibroid treatment. It is not indicated for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember that LNG-IUS is the preferred treatment for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia due to its local progesterone delivery, which causes endometrial atrophy. This condition has a lower risk of malignancy (~1%) compared to hyperplasia with atypia, which requires hysterectomy.

questions.text: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6th cranial nerve

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This can be remembered using the" This means that the Superior Oblique muscle is innervated by the 4th cranial nerve, the Lateral Rectus by the 6th cranial nerve, and the rest of the extraocular muscles are innervated by the 3rd cranial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, but not the lateral rectus.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. 7th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) is not involved in eye movement; it primarily controls facial muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve).

questions.text: If percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. what is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22%

 

Explanation:

 

  • By Chargaff’s rule, number of purines equal the number of pyrimidines in a double stranded DNA. So, amount of Adenine = Thymine. As Thymine is given as 28%, so total A+T is 56%.
  • Now also, amount of Guanine = Cytosine, as they pair with each other by three hydrogen bonds.
    Remaining 44% (100-56) equally distributed in 22% each for guanine and cytosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, thymine (T) always pairs with adenine (A), forming a complementary base pair. Similarly, cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). The base pairing in DNA is always complementary, and the total percentage of purines (adenine + guanine) equals the total percentage of pyrimidines (thymine + cytosine).
